variant.question: A crew plan for a full flap landing (30⁰) but, due to distraction, fail to extend flaps from the approach to the landing setting until a few seconds before touchdown. Which of the following statements is correct assuming the correct glidepath was flown to touchdown?

options.text: The aircraft is likely to float and touch down further along the runway.
There is no problem if the aircraft attitude is not changed.
There is less risk of a hard landing.

variant.question:
Refer to the image. 
Which type of flap is shown in the figure?
When Fowler type trailing edge flaps are extended at a constant angle of attack, the following changes will occur:

options.text: CL decreases, while the centre of lift shifts forward.
CL increases, while CD remains constant.
CD decreases, while the centre of lift shifts aft.

variant.question: When Fowler type trailing edge flaps are extended at a constant angle of attack, the following changes will occur:

options.text: CL increases and the centre of pressure moves forward.
CD decreases and the centre of pressure moves aft.
CL increases and CD remains constant.

variant.question: A slotted flap will increase the CLMAX by:

options.text: increasing the camber of the aerofoil and re-energising the airflow.
increasing only the camber of the aerofoil.
increasing the critical angle of attack.

variant.question: In the initial climb after take-off, flaps are accidentally retracted prematurely. The effect might be:

options.text: Stall warning, with a high risk a full stall.
Less drag, so thrust should be reduced.
A lower nose attitude is essential, in all situations
Less drag. Climb rate will increase

variant.question: During straight and level flight, the pilot starts extending flaps to the landing configuration. Due to a malfunction, the trailing edge flaps on the right wing remain retracted. If the malfunction goes unnoticed, the possible consequence is:

options.text: The aircraft will roll to the right and the right wing could stall.
The aircraft will roll to the left and the left wing could stall.
The aircraft will roll to the right and the left wing could stall.
The aircraft will roll to the left and the right wing could stall.

variant.question: A plain flap will increase CL~MAX~ by:

options.text: increasing the camber of the aerofoil.

variant.question: What is the most effective flap system?
A crew calculate speeds for a take-off using 15⁰ of flap but, due to distraction, perform the take off with flaps fully retracted. Which statement is true?

options.text: The aircraft may remain on the ground after rotation.
With better acceleration, the risk of a tail strike or stall is reduced.
With better acceleration, runway used on take-off will be less.
Once safely airborne, climb performance is reduced.

variant.question: A medium sized jet is on final approach, the pilots configure for a full flaps landing. The left wing leading-edge slats do not extend. Which statement is true?

options.text: The aircraft's left wing stalls if speed decreases
The aircraft's right wing stalls if speed decreases
The aircraft's left wing stalls if speed increases

variant.question: During an approach and coming to land, the pilots configure for full flaps landing. However, the left leading edge slats do not extend. Which statement is true?

options.text: The left wing may stall if speed decreases.
The right wing stalls if speed increases/decreases.
The left wing may stall if speed increases.

variant.question: Trailing edge flap extension will:

options.text: decrease the critical angle of attack and increase the value of CLMAX.
increase the critical angle of attack and increase the value of CLMAX.
decrease the critical angle of attack and decrease the value of CLMAX.
increase the critical angle of attack and decrease the value of CLMAX.

variant.question: Trailing edge flap extension will:

options.text: decrease the critical angle of attack and increase the value of CL~MAX~.
increase the critical angle of attack and decrease the value of CL~MAX~.
increase the critical angle of attack and increase the value of CL~MAX~.
decrease the critical angle of attack and decrease the value of CL~MAX~.

variant.question:
An aircraft maintaining straight and level with no flaps deployed, has an airfoil with C~L~ = 0.38. If the pilot extends the flaps, what will happen to the C~L~?
The new C~L~ will be...

options.text: higher than 0.38 to maintain the same altitude.
0.38, because you are still at the same altitude.
higher than 0.38 because flaps always increase the CL.

variant.question: Some wings are designed with a smaller angle of incidence towards the wing tip or a profile with a different camber towards the wing tip. The reason for this is to...

options.text: delay the stall at the wing tip to reduce the likelihood of the aeroplane experiencing significant rolling moments when stalled.
reduce the stalling angle of attack at the wing tips to ensure the wing tips stall first so there is a more gradual loss of lift when stalling.
evenly spread the lift across the wing planform and increase its efficiency, resulting in minimum drag at the optimum angle of attack.
ensure that the entire wing stall occurs when the aeroplane is at a specific pitch angle, and to create an aeroplane with predictable stall characteristics.

variant.question: When flaps are retracted at constant angle of attack the lift coefficient will:

options.text: vary as the square of IAS.

variant.question: While performing an obstacle limited take-off, you inadvertently set a lower take-off flap setting (less flap) than the calculated and required. Compared to a take-off at the correct flap setting , the aircraft will pass the departure end of the runway at...

options.text: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that a greater take-off distance is required.
greater height, as the lower flap setting means that more lift is generated.
lower height, as the lower flap setting means that more drag is generated.
greater height, as the lower flap setting means that a shorter take-off distance is required.

variant.question: A crew calculate landing speeds for a full flap landing (30⁰) but, due to distraction, omit to extend flaps further than the approach setting (15⁰). Which of the following statements is correct assuming the correct glidepath was flown to touchdown?

options.text: Landing Distance available may be insufficient and a tail strike is more likely.
There is less risk of a runway overrun.
Thrust setting on the approach will be higher than expected.
Aircraft attitude on the glideslope will be lower than expected.

variant.question: Refer to figure. Which of the augmentations in the annex will increase the wings C~L~?
When deploying the flaps the effective angle of attack

options.text: May increase or decrease depending on the aircraft type

variant.question: Compared with the clean configuration, the angle of attack at CLMAX with trailing edge flaps extended is

options.text: smaller or larger depending on the degree of flap extension.

variant.question: While performing the “After Engine Start” procedures, the pilots of a commercial jet aircraft forget to set the slats/flaps in the calculated take-off position. What could be a consequence of this action?

options.text: Acceleration will be lower, but a safe take-off will be conducted.
There would be insufficient elevator authority such that the aeroplane will NOT rotate.
A safe to take-off will be possible as this case is considered in the V~R~ calculation.

variant.question: Under what configuration is the aircraft at maximum C~L~/C~D~ ratio?

Refer to figure 081-38.
Which of the following devices shows a slotted flap system?
How will the takeoff distance change if the flaps are increased from 0 to full?

options.text: Reduce until medium flap setting, then increase

variant.question: After taking off from a runway and during climb, the pilot forgets to retract the flaps. What are the consequences?

options.text: The aircraft climb gradient will decrease and the risk of exceeding VFE.
The aircraft climb gradient will not be affected and risk of structural damage.
The aircraft climb gradient will increase and the risk of exceeding VFE.

variant.question: Deployment of trailing edge flaps will reduce the angle of attack at which CLmax is reached. The design of flap used to minimise this effect is:
When extending the trailing edge flaps the effective angle of attack:

options.text: may increase or decrease depending on the aircraft type.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 When compared to a clean configuration, the wing in the attached figure has a:

options.text: higher C~L~ and a lower C~L~-C~D~ ratio
lower C~D~ and a lower CL-C~D~ ratio

variant.question: (For this question use the image in the annex). Which type of flap is shown in the figure?
Which type of flap is shown in the picture 4?
Which type of flap is shown in the picture 3?
When approaching to land, the pilot forgets to lower the flaps. What is going to happen to the LDR, drag and speed at threshold?
When flaps are deployed at constant angle of attack the lift coefficient will

options.text: vary as the square of IAS.

variant.question: The flaps are retracted and the angle of attack is maintained. What happens to the lift coefficient?

options.text: The lift coefficient will vary with the square of IAS.
The lift coefficient will remain the constant as well.

variant.question:
Cambered wing sections give ....(1).... maximum CL at
....(2).... angles of attack.
When you have your flaps in clean configuration and lower the trailing edge flaps for takeoff configuration what happens to the airplane?
The type of flap which extends rearward from the trailing edge of the wing as it is lowered is called:

Refer to figure.  
  Which type of flap is shown in the picture 3?

Refer to figure.  
  Which type of flap is shown in the picture 4?
A plane is flying at 1,8 Vs, what % of C~LMAX~ is that?

Before takeoff, the pilot decides for an an intermediate flap setting due to climb performance. After engine start, a greater flap setting is selected by mistake. In these circumstances, the rotation speed will be (1) _____ and climb performance will be (2) _____.
Assume that an aircraft is performing a series of take-off in different flap configurations. If the flaps are lowered the take-off distance required is _____.

options.text: The same as with flaps not used.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 081-51.
After take off a pilot retracts the trailing edge flaps, but the right flaps become stuck in the down position. What control inputs must the pilot make to counter this flap asymmetry?
After engine start, the pilots forget to lower the flap setting for departure. What is the consequence of this?

options.text: Airplane may not lift off the runway
Take-off is safe if the performance / Rotation speed is calculated.
Aircraft will certainly stall after take-off, when airborne.

variant.question: Compared to a wing with less camber, a more cambered wing will:

options.text: Shock stall at a higher alpha
Shock stall at a higher Mach Number

variant.question: You are on an approach when extending flaps, due to a malfunction the right flap does not extend. What will happen to the aircraft?

options.text: Plane will bank right and right wing may stall.
Plane will bank right and left wing may stall.
Plane will go into a spin.
Plane will bank left and right wing may stall.
